Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Fluorescent Fingerprinting of Dissolved Organic Matter as a Monitoring Tool in Reclaimed Water

POR.DRECONTENT:
Water shortages due to unpredictable climate change and inconsistent population impacts have increasingly led to the development of centralized recycled water systems, where extensively treated wastewater is diverted for non-potable applications including irrigation and industrial use and most recently indirect potable reuse (injection into groundwater aquifers which feed drinking water treatment facilities). Because treatment failures and cross connections between recycled and drinking water pipelines can occur, there is a need for development of an on-line, real time water quality monitoring system. Previous studies suggest that there is a significant difference between the fluorescent signatures of dissolved organic matter (DOM – a naturally occuring water quality parameter in all water sources) from recycled and drinking water (depending on recycled water use) such that even at very low intrusion levels (cross connection mixtures of recycled and drinking water), monitoring the water system with fluorescence spectroscopy will serve as a tool to detect contamination events and treatment failures. The expected outcome of this research is the basic knowledge and likely effectiveness of a new monitoring approach based on distinct fluorescence signatures of recycled and drinking water quality. It is expected that this monitoring approach has the potential to be a very sensitive tool that could be broadly applied to different recycled and drinking water systems to enhance monitoring treatment processes and throughout the distribution system; ultimately preventing contamination events that are potentially harmful to public health, while improving confidence in water utilities worldwide.

This research contributed to my Master's thesis at UNC-Chapel Hill in the US while forging a new collaboration with the Curtin Water Quality Research Centre in Perth, Australia. My experience has exposed me to an excellent new network of researchers, institutions and new culture where water scarcity has reached a more significant level than my current location in NC, such that cutting edge work, resources and trials have been allocated, piloted and implemented in an attempt to understand, improve and explore the sustainability of water resources. It also that has significantly contributed to my professional development and growth as a scientist and engineer, which I will carry with me wherever my career may take me.

For more information about the entire experience, see my blog at http://rpolera2.blogspot.com/ 

 

Rory A. Polera, MS Environmental Engineering
Department of Environmental Sciences & Engineering
Gillings School of Global Public Health
University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
